turns.content: What is the best free tool for converting text to vocals for a song?

There are several free text-to-speech (TTS) tools available that you can use to convert your text into vocals for a song. Some popular options include:

1. NaturalReader: This is a free TTS software that can convert your text to vocals with a natural-sounding voice. You can adjust the voice speed, pitch, and volume to suit your needs. NaturalReader is available for both Windows and Mac.
2. Balabolka: This is another free TTS software that allows you to convert your text to speech with different voices and languages. You can also save the converted text as an audio file. Balabolka is only available for Windows.
3. Google Text-to-Speech: This is a free service provided by Google that can convert your text into natural-sounding speech. You can use the service in various Google apps, such as Google Translate or Google Play Books. However, you cannot save the speech as an audio file.
4. Amazon Polly: This is a cloud-based TTS service offered by Amazon that can convert your text into lifelike speech. Amazon Polly offers a free tier with limited usage per month, after which you need to pay for additional usage.

Ultimately, the best tool for you will depend on your specific needs and preferences. You can try out a few of these options to see which one works best for you.
Do any of the above tools have options for the voice to sing the text?

The tools mentioned above are primarily designed for text-to-speech conversion, which means they focus on producing natural-sounding spoken words rather than singing. However, there are other software and tools available that specialize in converting text to singing voices.

One such tool is called "Vocaloid," which is a voice synthesis software that uses recorded voice samples of singers and generates a singing voice based on the input text. Vocaloid is not free, but it is a popular tool used by many music producers to create virtual singers for their songs.

Another option is to use a digital audio workstation (DAW) like FL Studio or Ableton Live, which includes built-in virtual instruments that can generate singing voices based on input notes and MIDI data. These DAWs often come with pre-made vocal samples that can be manipulated and edited to fit your needs.

In summary, if you are looking for tools specifically designed for converting text to singing voices, you may need to explore options beyond the ones mentioned above. Vocaloid and digital audio workstations are some popular options you may want to consider.
